text: Islands rock or reef so why is this such
an important question for the South
China Sea well if you own an island
under international law you have
exclusive economic rights to an area 200
nautical miles around your islands you
could look for fish you can search for
oil or gas but in order to be classified
as an island it has to be able to
support human life so thanks do you know
that means that they must have fresh
water and very few of the features in
the South China Sea have that so most of
them are likely to be classified as
rocks which basically means that they
just about stay out of the water
at high tide and rocks have a much
smaller entitlement to water only 12
nautical miles around the rock and then
there's reefs which go underwater at
high tide now you can't own a reef it
belongs to the seabed and whoever has
rights to that particular bit of seabed
now China has occupied several of the
reefs in the South China Sea and if you
can just help me again you know that's
great and China has dredged the waters
around the reefs and put sand cement on
top of the reef effectively turning it
into an island they've even put air
strips on some of them now under
international law an artificial island
has no legal basis but as you can see
whether something is classified as an
island a rock or indeed a reef has huge
implications legally for who controls
what in the South China Sea
you
